item.title: Can E-Way Bill functionality be implemented on a custom DocType?
item.dc:creator: tejalkumbhar
item.description:
In ERPNext, E-Way Bill functionality is available by default for standard DocTypes like Sales Invoice and Delivery Note.

I want to understand whether it is technically supported to implement E-Way Bill generation on a custom DocType (for example: Gate Pass / Custom Delivery Challan / Material Outward).

Specifically:

  • Can we trigger E-Way Bill generation from any custom DocType?

  • Is there any framework-level restriction on using E-Way Bill APIs only with standard DocTypes?

  • Has anyone implemented E-Way Bill integration on a custom form using a GSP (ClearTax / Masters India, etc.)?

Looking for guidance or best practices from the community.

1 post - 1 participant

Read full topic
item.source: Can E-Way Bill functionality be implemented on a custom DocType?

item.title: Bug: Unable to Define Multiple Item Tax Templates with Different Validity Periods and Min/Max Amount
item.dc:creator: loginid24x7
item.description:
While configuring Item Tax Templates for GST compliance, I encountered a serious limitation in the Item Tax Template Valid From / Min-Max Amount feature.

The system does not allow defining the same Item Tax Template more than once , even if:

  • The Valid From dates are different, and
  • The Min Amount / Max Amount ranges are different.

This becomes a problem in real-world tax scenarios where the tax structure changes over time but for the same item category and tax template.

Real Example: Footwear GST Slab Change (India)

Here’s a real GST compliance scenario that demonstrates the problem:

  • Before 22 Sept 2025:
    • GST on footwear above ₹1000 → 18%
  • From 22 Sept 2025 onwards:
    • GST on footwear above ₹2500 → 18%

In this case, we must define two valid tax conditions for the same item tax template :

  1. One for invoices before 22 Sep 2025 (Valid From: e.g., 01 Jan 2025 – 21 Sep 2025)
  2. Another for invoices on or after 22 Sep 2025 (Valid From: 22 Sep 2025 onwards)

However, ERPNext blocks this configuration because it does not allow creating the same Item Tax Template again, even if the date range and min/max conditions differ.

1 post - 1 participant

Read full topic
item.source: Bug: Unable to Define Multiple Item Tax Templates with Different Validity Periods and Min/Max Amount

item.title: Need Ability to Generate E-Waybill for Internal Stock Transfers Across States
item.dc:creator: Dhruvil_Mistry
item.description:
Our company has a single branch but regularly transfers stock internally to engineers located in different states. Although these are internal transfers (not sales), an e-waybill is still legally required.

Currently, on ERPNext v15 with the Indian Compliance app, we are looking for a way to generate e-waybills for such internal stock transfers directly from the system. Is this an existing feature, or would it require a new enhancement? Please guide us on this.

2 posts - 2 participants

Read full topic
item.source: Need Ability to Generate E-Waybill for Internal Stock Transfers Across States

item.title: Using a Custom “Selling Rate” Field in Stock Entry Instead of Basic Rate for E-Waybill
item.dc:creator: Dhruvil_Mistry
item.description:
Hello everyone,

We’ve added a custom field called “Selling Rate” in the Stock Entry doctype. Our goal is to use this field as the Basic Rate when generating the e-waybill — essentially replacing the default basic_rate with our new selling_rate field.

Has anyone implemented something similar or can guide us on the best approach to override the existing logic so that the e-waybill picks up Selling Rate instead of Basic Rate?

Any suggestions, examples, or best practices would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you!

6 posts - 4 participants

Read full topic
item.source: Using a Custom “Selling Rate” Field in Stock Entry Instead of Basic Rate for E-Waybill

item.title: Need advice regarding India Compliance app
item.dc:creator: shrey
item.description:
Hi all.
I’m new to ERPNext and India Compliance app.
Have currently set up ERPNext in Frappe Cloud, along with the India Compliance app.

But before i fully delve into using these apps, i have a few queries that i could use some expert advise on:

  1. Is India Compliance app, in itself, sufficient to fulfill all the necessary Compliance/GST/IT related activities within ERPNext, without depending on any of the ERPNext’s existing modules?
  2. Does it fully encompass all the ‘Indian accounting’ compliance related activities that a company could need?
  3. Also, how well do customisations/integrations in ERPNext play with the India Compliance app? Does this app require any additional/special consideration when ERPNext customisations/integrations are implemented?
  4. Is ERPNext + Indian Compliance app, a 100% replacement for any other accounting system (Tally, Vyapar, Busy etc.)?

Thanks in advance.

4 posts - 3 participants

Read full topic
item.source: Need advice regarding India Compliance app

item.title: Directly selecting Tax Category in Supplier and Customer master is creating this issue
item.dc:creator: Abid_Khan
item.description:
If an Item Tax Template is selected in the Item Master, and a Tax Category is directly selected in the Supplier or Customer master or in the transaction document, it may cause an issue where the tax template is not applied to the item. To resolve this, I remove the In-State or Out-State Tax Category from the current document and it is working fine.

In below Image you can see Template is visible to select when Tax Category is not selected

In this below image you can see Tax template is not visible if I select Tax Category

2 posts - 2 participants

Read full topic
item.source: Directly selecting Tax Category in Supplier and Customer master is creating this issue

item.title: Getting “Invalid depends_on expression” while adding item – India Compliance Installed
item.dc:creator: Sowmyah
item.description:
Hi all,
I’m getting the following error when I click “Add Item” in a form (e.g., Sales Invoice, Purchase Order, etc.):

Invalid “depends_on” expression

Here’s the context:

  • I recently installed the India Compliance app.
  • The error started appearing after that.
  • I checked the field setup, and none of the visible fields seem to have a depends_on value.
  • Running bench migrate doesn’t show any error.
  • Using ERPNext version: [v15.57.4]
  • Frappe version: [v15.63.1]

Logs don’t clearly show where this is failing. Any idea how to debug or fix this? Could it be from a custom field that was added silently during install?

Any help is appreciated!

Thanks in advance.

5 posts - 5 participants

Read full topic
item.source: Getting “Invalid depends_on expression” while adding item – India Compliance Installed

item.title: Port address as ship to address for export invoice when generating einvoice and ewb
item.dc:creator: Basant
item.description:
There is a change on e_invoice util that breaks the desired functionality. As per the GST guideline, while generating an einvoice for export that will also generate ewb, port address is to be sent as ship-to address.

Point no 28 from invoice portal : Generate IRN
In case of export transactions for goods, if e-way bill is required along with IRN, then the 'Ship-To' address should be of the place/port in India from where the goods are being exported. Otherwise E-way bill can be generated later based on IRN, by passing the 'Ship-To' address as the place/port address of India from where the goods are being exported .

It was correctly done but this change in Dec 2024 breaks the correct functionality. Can we please revert it to the original behaviour?

@Smit_Vora @Sanket_Shah

2 posts - 2 participants

Read full topic
item.source: Port address as ship to address for export invoice when generating einvoice and ewb

item.title: Sales Return addresses
item.dc:creator: Basant
item.description:
In case of Sales return EWB, the dispatch address will either be of the customer or transporter while recipient address will be that of the seller. However, the functionality doesn’t work that way today. It continues to follow the same methodology as for initial sales dispatch.
Also, ewb document type should be Delivery Challan (in case EWB is being generated independently)

Refer to the following note in the URL: How to generate an E-way Bill if the goods are rejected by the recipient?

NOTE: As an inward E-way bill, the recipient’s GSTIN and address will always be of the supplier in all the cases.

Also, watch this video (8:15 mins onwards): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=32wW9SlCE4s&ab_channel=TheMauryaAFTClasses

5 posts - 2 participants

Read full topic
item.source: Sales Return addresses
